pr_title: Introduce table cache quota to HiveConnector

timeline.bodyText: Given we have three states here, have we considered using enum as opposed to Optional<Boolean>.
timeline.author: shixuan-fan

replies.bodyText: I agree, the usage of optional is confusing. Let's use proper states.
replies.author: jainxrohit

replies.bodyText: I also think, we should not use hiveFileContext in the cacheManager. Lets keep the cacheManage simple and should not be aware of HiveFileContext
replies.author: jainxrohit

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't this be a DataSize instead?
timeline.author: shixuan-fan

timeline.bodyText: Probably extract this to a method so we don't need to add the comment below.
timeline.author: shixuan-fan

replies.bodyText:
I dont think I understand this logic. Why get method has anything to do with cache quota?
Get method should just return the data if the data is present in the cache?
It is the put method responsibility to put the data in the cache or not. While putting more data to the cache, it should be checked if the new data can be accommodated in the cache or not.
replies.author: jainxrohit

replies.bodyText: Same, we don't wanna check quota on read. Move the checking and persisting cache logic to write.
replies.author: highker
kewang1024

timeline.bodyText: Maybe we should update the current cache usage here given there is an eviction event?
timeline.author: shixuan-fan

replies.author: kewang1024

timeline.bodyText: I think we should not introduce cache quota here, we can leave this as it is. The only part which should worry about cacheQuota is cache writing methods(put).
timeline.author: jainxrohit

replies.bodyText: Agree. We should not have cache quota check on any read path. We only check cache quota on put.
replies.author: highker

timeline.bodyText: qutoa => tableQuota?
timeline.author: jainxrohit

timeline.bodyText: This looks off. Doesn't seem like a correct place.
timeline.author: jainxrohit
highker

timeline.bodyText: Actually, we should always have quota instead of optional. We could potentially set it to be infinite to indicate there is no limit.
timeline.author: highker

timeline.bodyText: private final Map<Long, Set<Path>> scopeFiles = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();, where Long is gotten from CacheScopeHandle.getIdentifier()
timeline.author: highker

timeline.bodyText: You need to grab the read lock for range cacheRange.getLock().readLock(). CacheRange is not thread safe without lock.
timeline.author: highker

timeline.bodyText:
long
getCacheScopeSizeInBytes
This is an extremely expensive call that should not be tested for every read that misses a cache. Rather, we should have a single background thread populating the cache size for each scope and save it in Map<Long, Long>.

replies.bodyText:
Currently we can add logic for PARTITION directly, but it requires additional changes to add support for SCHEMA / CATALOG
I'm thinking having a minimal viable version and adding those support when needed
replies.author: kewang1024

replies.bodyText:
You don't need to do any refactoring to achieve this:

GLOBAL: "."
SCHEMA: databaseName
TABLE: databaseName + "." + tableName 
PARTITION: databaseName + "." + tableName + "." + internalSplit.getPartitionName()

It is very important to keep in mind that without fully qualified names, subscopes can have duplication even they are not.
replies.author: highker

@@ -22,13 +24,16 @@
 {
     /**
      * Given {@param request}, check if the data is in cache.
-     * If it is not in cache, return false.
-     * Otherwise, save the data in {@param buffer} starting at {@param offset} and return true.
+     * If it is in cache, save the data in {@param buffer} starting at {@param offset} and return IN_CACHE.
+     * If it is not in cache:
+     *      1. If there is still cache quota for this table, return NOT_IN_CACHE
+     *      2. Otherwise, return CACHE_QUOTA_EXCEED
+     * @return CacheResult
      */
-    boolean get(FileReadRequest request, byte[] buffer, int offset);
+    CacheResult get(CacheQuota cacheQuota, FileReadRequest request, byte[] buffer, int offset);

timeline.author: jainxrohit

timeline.bodyText: I think we should just create hash at the initialization time.
timeline.author: jainxrohit

timeline.bodyText: I think we discussed this. Didn't we think it would be better if we calculate these during put operation?
timeline.author: jainxrohit

replies.bodyText:
Yes, I thought we had an agreement back then? because in read method, we always hint the guava Cache, which is by the original design of our cache system.
That's why we have to check in the read operation if it exceeds quota to decide if we really want to hint the cache
And if we have checked in the read, checking again in put would be excessive
replies.author: kewang1024

replies.bodyText: Sounds good.
replies.author: jainxrohit

timeline.bodyText: Use HIVE_UNKNOWN_ERROR
timeline.author: highker

replies.bodyText:
I think it's more related to cache config not being supported, HIVE_UNKNOWN_ERROR   seems to be used more often for hive data related issues.
Also our next step might be breaking presto-cache and presto-hive, we need to add CACHE_SCOPE_NOT_SUPPORTED  back once that happens
Thus I think we can keep CACHE_SCOPE_NOT_SUPPORTED  but make it EXTERNAL like HIVE_UNKNOWN_ERROR
replies.author: kewang1024

replies.bodyText: We shouldn't create error codes for utilities. Error codes are meant for main engine or connectors. Check https://github.com/prestodb/presto/wiki/Error-Codes to see how we allocate error code space. If you really need to add a new error code, it should belong to HiveErrorCode
replies.author: highker

timeline.bodyText: This will be called on the coordinator. One concern is the complexity of md5(). I'm not sure if md5() is more expensive or shipping the identity is..... To be save, I would just move this part of logic to getIdentifier() call.
timeline.author: highker

replies.bodyText:
Valid point.
Since HiveSplit already has all the identity information we need, instead of passing Identity(could be expensive) we just pass the Scope info to worker and let worker reuse identity from HiveSplit and calculate the identifier there
replies.author: kewang1024

timeline.bodyText:
Nice, we changed it from schedule!
In general, do we know how many files exist in the cache directory? It would be worthwhile to know the impact of building this in every few seconds. I would have preferred to do this asynchronously whenever we write any files to cache.
timeline.author: jainxrohit

replies.bodyText: Actually we don't and also it should vary from different use case. I can try to see if we can add any indicator for us to tell the impact
replies.author: kewang1024

timeline.bodyText: what is CacheScopeHandle? is this a typo?
timeline.author: apc999

replies.bodyText: It actually means the handle that's extract from CacheScope, but seems a bit confusing then, I can change it
replies.author: kewang1024

timeline.bodyText: is this intentional to hard-code the cache recalculation rate?
timeline.author: apc999

replies.bodyText: It is not. Because this is more of an experimental feature to foresee all the work we would need from alluxio and also finalize on the communication protocol and configs from our side
replies.author: kewang1024

timeline.bodyText:
Though cacheScopeFiles and cacheScopeSizeInBytes are threadsafe, the operations on these two data structures are not really atomic to each other.  E.g., the recalculation executor can run concurrently with ifExceedQuota, and leave operations on cacheScopeFiles and cacheScopeSizeInBytes interleaved in multiple threads.
I don't see an immediate thread-safety risk on this in addition to some calculation that might be a bit "off".
Just make sure we are aware of it --- the cache capacity & quota calculation may not be fully accurate
timeline.author: apc999

replies.bodyText: You're right, here, the cache capacity & quota calculation would be an estimation, like I said it would an experimental feature, it would be served more as an evaluation and provide basic protection from bad table data abusing the system
replies.author: kewang1024

timeline.bodyText: is this change independent?
timeline.author: apc999

replies.bodyText: it's related to our change; because we don't want to hint the cache if we already reached our limitation
replies.author: kewang1024

timeline.bodyText: do you document anywhere what it means by returning Optiona.empty()? assuming it means no limitation?
timeline.author: apc999

replies.bodyText: I plan to add those things to the requirement doc later on, yes, it means no limitation
replies.author: kewang1024
